images.copyright: Nazca boobies, Wolf Island, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador (© Tui De Roy/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Waiting to 'Galápa-go'
images.caption: Nazca boobies, Wolf Island, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador
images.desc: The Galápagos Islands in the eastern Pacific are a paradise for wildlife. Its habitats range from arid regions to tropical rainforests. Because these islands are so isolated, many of the species that live here are not found anywhere else in the world. One species found in abundance is the Nazca booby, pictured here on Wolf Island. The name of these striking birds might raise a few eyebrows, but it actually comes from the Spanish word 'bobo,' meaning clown, because of the birds' clumsy demeanour when they're walking.

og.title: Nazca boobies, Wolf Island, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador
og.desc: The Galápagos Islands in the eastern Pacific are a paradise for wildlife. Its habitats range from arid regions to tropical rainforests…

images.copyright: Sunrise at Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming (© Kurt Budliger/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Where the deer and the antelope play
images.caption: Sunrise at Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming, USA
images.desc: Mind-blowing beauty like the kind pictured in today's image is one reason people keep coming back to Wyoming, US, and the Grand Teton National Park. Named 'les trois tétons' by early French trappers, the Grand Teton National Park was created in 1929 by conservationists including John D. Rockefeller Jr. The park is home to a virtually untouched ecosystem of plants and animals, such as grizzly bears, wolves, bison, moose and bald eagles.
images.bsTitle: Where the deer and the antelope play

images.copyright: Two Atlantic puffins, Elliston, Newfoundland, Canada (© Daphne Roberts Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Puffins with a plan
images.caption: Two Atlantic puffins in Elliston
images.desc: In Elliston, Newfoundland and Labrador, Atlantic puffins, like the ones in today's image, draw onlookers with their black and white plumage and orange beaks. As well as in Newfoundland and Labrador in Canada, these seabirds breed in several countries, including Russia, Iceland, Norway, and Greenland. These 'sea parrots' have a wingspan of 47 to 63 centimetres and travel vast distances to mate. Surprisingly, the colour of their beaks changes seasonally; during the breeding season, it is brighter with a hint of yellow and orange. However, in the nonbreeding season, the beak sheds its yellow highlight.

og.title: Two Atlantic puffins in Elliston

images.copyright: Huntington Beach Pier, California, at sunset (© Stan Moniz Photography/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: A peerless pier
images.caption: Huntington Beach Pier, California, USA
images.desc: In today's image, we see the sun beginning to disappear below the pier at Huntington Beach, California, US. First built in 1902, Huntington Beach Pier was damaged by a storm, leading it to be rebuilt just nine years later. During the Second World War, a submarine lookout post was installed on the pier to help with the war effort. These days, it's a popular tourist spot, with visitors heading there to fish and watch surfers ride the waves out in the Pacific Ocean.

images.copyright: Alfanzina lighthouse, Algarve, Portugal (© Andreas Kunz/Getty Images)
images.title: Light the way
images.caption: International Lighthouse and Lightship Weekend
images.desc: The lighthouse featured in today's image stands in Carvoeiro in the Algarve on the southern coast of Portugal. Built in 1919, the Alfanzina lighthouse shines out over the ocean to help ships navigate the dangerous waters that surround the area. A popular tourist destination, the lighthouse also has become a symbol of the region's deep links to the sea.

images.copyright: Canadian International Air Show at the Canadian National Exhibition, in Toronto, Ontario (© Tony Florio/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Look up, Toronto!
images.caption: Canadian National Exhibition 2024
images.desc: Come one, come all, to the Canadian National Exhibition (CNE)—a time-honoured tradition held from August 16 to September 2 in Toronto. As the sun sets, the grounds of the CNE will come alive with live performances from artists and bands like Doriann Forrester, James Naro and Kyle Layton, Sloan, and MacKenzie Porter. A lineup that spans all musical tastes, from toe-tapping country beats to electric pop rhythms—there's a song for every taste. As well as music, there's plenty more to do; go for a ride on the Century Wheel or the Berry Go Round, or take part in games like the Peewee Baseball Tournament and Girls Fastball Tournament.

images.copyright: Hang Sơn Đoòng cave, Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park, Vietnam (© Geng Xu/Getty Images)
images.title: A 'hole' new world
images.caption: Hang Sơn Đoòng, Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park, Vietnam
images.desc: In 1991, a Vietnamese logger stumbled upon something big in Vietnam's Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park. During a jungle expedition, he found the entrance to a cave with a roaring underground river, which was later named Hang Sơn Đoòng or 'cave of the mountain river.' In 2009, the British Cave Research Association led an expedition to explore the site. It was then that they realised something incredible: it was the world's largest cave. How large, you ask? Hang Sơn Đoòng's main passage is 5 kilometres long, 150 metres wide and 200 metres high. That's tall enough to fit a 40-storey skyscraper! Inside, there is a 60-metre calcite barrier called the 'Great Wall of Vietnam' and stalagmites stretching as tall as 80 metres.

og.title: Hang Sơn Đoòng, Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park, Vietnam

images.copyright: Thorny devil, Watarrka National Park, Australia (© Yva Momatiuk and John Eastcott/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Feeling sharp today
images.caption: World Lizard Day
images.copyrightonly: © Yva Momatiuk and John Eastcott/Minden Pictures
images.desc: From mythology to modern media, lizards have often been portrayed as scary reptiles. As it turns out, they're not as dangerous as stories might lead you to believe. Today, World Lizard Day, is the perfect time to learn about these cold-blooded creatures. With more than 7,000 species, these animals have adapted to a wide range of environments—from deserts to rainforests. Take the gecko, for example. These little climbers have specialised toe pads that let them scale walls and even walk on ceilings. Then there's the chameleon, known for its colour-changing skin. While many think it's all about blending in, chameleons also change colour to communicate and regulate their temperature.

og.title: World Lizard Day
og.desc: From mythology to modern media, lizards have often been portrayed as scary reptiles. As it turns out, they're not as dangerous as stories…
